thread.title: Fielding miscues allow Mets to regain the lead in the fifth

title: Fielding miscues allow Mets to regain the lead in the fifth
text:
Just as the Cubs evened Game 1 of the NLCS up at one run each, the Mets jumped back out ahead, taking advantage of a fielding mistake.
With one out and runners on first and second, Mets pitcher Matt Harvey bunted the ball to a charging Anthony Rizzo. The Cubs first baseman quickly got the ball over to third base for the force out. With Harvey still running down the line, Bryant fumbled the ball, unable to turn the double play.
While the Cubs did get the lead runner, it kept the inning alive for leadoff hitter Curtis Granderson. The Mets outfielder flipped a ball into center field, bringing home Juan Lagaras.
#Chicago on Chicago crime. #NLCS pic.twitter.com/HMi9cufWxi
â€” Matthew Schwerha (@MSchwerha) October 18, 2015
The Mets would only get one run in the inning, but it was enough to regain the lead. New York scored first in the first inning off of a Daniel Murphy Home Run.
The game was briefly tied after a Starlin Castro double brought home Anthony Rizzo.
